trans-unit.source: Provides compilation services for ASP.NET applications.
The <xref:System.Web.Compilation.ClientBuildManager> class offers methods and properties for compiling ASP.NET Web applications, and retrieving the generated assemblies or generated source code.
Instances of the class are established in the client's application domain and provide access to the ASP.NET build system outside of Microsoft Internet Information Services (IIS).
The class can be used to develop customized tools for compiling Web applications.
The command-line tool `aspnet_compiler` uses the <xref:System.Web.Compilation.ClientBuildManager> class.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Web.Compilation.ClientBuildManager"></xref> class without a specified target directory or precompilation flags.
The virtual path to the application root.
The physical path to the application root.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Web.Compilation.ClientBuildManager"></xref> class with the specified target directory.
This form of the constructor is typically used with precompilation, as it specifies a precompilation target directory.
The virtual path to the application root.
The physical path to the application root.
The target directory for precompilation.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Web.Compilation.ClientBuildManager"></xref> class with the specified target directory and compilation parameter.
This form of the constructor is typically used with precompilation, as it specifies a precompilation target directory and precompilation flags.
The virtual path to the application root.
The physical path to the application root.
The target directory for precompilation.
Values that determine the precompilation behavior.

Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Web.Compilation.ClientBuildManager"></xref> class by using the specified virtual directory, source directory, target directory, compilation parameter, and type-description provider.
The virtual path of the application root.
The physical path of the application root.
The target directory for precompilation.
Values that determine the precompilation behavior.
The type-description provider to use.
This parameter is primarily used to support the multi-targeting infrastructure in Visual Studio.
It is used to retrieve metadata about types that is filtered for specific versions of the .NET Framework.
Occurs when an application domain is shut down.
Occurs when an application domain is started.
Occurs when an application domain is unloaded.
Gets the physical path to the directory used for code generation.
The directory for code generation is typically in the temporary ASP.NET files directory.
A <xref href="System.String"></xref> containing the directory path used for code generation.
Compiles application-dependent files, such as files in the App_Code directory, the Global.asax file, resource files, and Web references.

The <xref:System.Web.Compilation.ClientBuildManager.CompileApplicationDependencies%2A> method ensures that resources, Web references, files in the App_Code directory, .browser files in the App_Browsers directory, and the Global.asax file are compiled.
Compiles the file represented by the virtual path.
The path to the file to be compiled.
Compiles the file represented by the virtual path and provides a callback class to receive status information about the build.
The path to the file to be compiled.
The object to receive status information from compilation.
virtualPath is null.
Creates an object in the application domain of the ASP.NET runtime.
The type of object to be created.
`true` to throw an exception if the object has already been created in the application domain of the ASP.NET runtime; otherwise, `false`.
An object in the application domain of the ASP.NET runtime.
type is `null`.
The object already exists in the application domain and failIfExists is `true`.
Generates code from the contents of a file.
The virtual path to the file.
The contents of the file.
When this method returns, contains a dictionary of line pragmas.
A <xref href="System.String"></xref> containing the generated code.
virtualPath is null.
Returns the codeDOM tree, compiler type, and compiler parameters for a file represented by a virtual path.
The <xref:System.Web.Compilation.ClientBuildManager.GenerateCodeCompileUnit%2A> method retrieves information needed to compile a file.
In addition to a <xref:System.CodeDom.CodeCompileUnit> object as a return value, it returns three `out` parameters.
The `codeDomProviderType` parameter returns the provider type for generating and compiling the file.
The `compilerParameters` parameter contains properties that determine compilation behavior.
The `linePragmasTable` parameter contains a dictionary of line pragmas.
The virtual path to the file.
When this method returns, contains the codeDOM provider type used for code generation and compilation.
When this method returns, contains the properties that define how the file will be compiled.
When this method returns, contains a dictionary of line pragmas.
A <xref href="System.CodeDom.CodeCompileUnit"></xref> for the given file.
Returns the contents, codeDOM tree, compiler type, and compiler parameters for a file represented by a virtual path.
The <xref:System.Web.Compilation.ClientBuildManager.GenerateCodeCompileUnit%2A> method retrieves information needed to compile a file.
In addition to a <xref:System.CodeDom.CodeCompileUnit> object as a return value, it returns three `out` parameters.
The `codeDomProviderType` parameter returns the provider type for generating and compiling the file.
The `compilerParameters` parameter contains properties that determine compilation behavior.
The `linePragmasTable` parameter contains a dictionary of line pragmas.
The virtual path to the file.
The contents of the file represented by the virtualPath parameter.
When this method returns, contains the codeDOM provider type used for code generation and compilation.
When this method returns, contains the properties that define how the file represented by the virtualPath parameter will be compiled.
When this method returns, contains a dictionary of line pragmas.
A <xref href="System.CodeDom.CodeCompileUnit"></xref> for the given file.
virtualPath is null.
Gets the directories with files that, when changed, cause the application domain to shut down.
Changes to files in specific top-level directories cause the application domain to shut down.
Files within the Bin, App_Code, Global_Resources, Web References, and App_Browsers directories are monitored to detect any changes.
When changes are detected, the application domain is shut down.
A <xref href="System.String"></xref> array containing the top-level directory names.
Gets a collection of browser elements.
The <xref:System.Collections.IDictionary> object contains browser names for the keys and <xref:System.Web.UI.Triplet> objects for the values.
The <xref:System.Web.UI.Triplet> objects each contain the name of the parent browser element, a description, and the depth of the browser element in the tree.
An <xref href="System.Collections.IDictionary"></xref> containing browser elements.
Gets information about the compiler type, compiler parameters, and the directory in which to store code files generated from non-code files such as .wsdl files.
The <xref:System.Web.Compilation.ClientBuildManager.GetCodeDirectoryInformation%2A> method retrieves information needed to build a code directory.
It returns this information through three `out` parameters.
The `codeDomProviderType` parameter returns the provider type for generating and compiling the files in the code directory.
The `compilerParameters` parameter contains properties that determine compilation behavior.
The `generatedFilesDir` parameter stores the directory path containing all the code files generated from non-code files in the code directory, such as .wsdl files.
The directory about which to retrieve information.
When this method returns, contains the provider type used for code generation and compilation.
When this method returns, contains the properties that define how the file will be compiled.
When this method returns, contains the directory for files generated from non-code files.
virtualCodeDir is null.
Compiles the file represented by the virtual path and returns its compiled type.
The virtual path of the file to compile.
The <xref href="System.Type"></xref> of the compiled file.
virtualPath is null.
Returns the compiler type and parameters that are used to build a file represented by a virtual path.
The virtual path to the file.
When this method returns, contains the provider type used for code generation and compilation.
When this method returns, contains the properties that define how the file will be compiled.
virtualPath is null.
Returns the virtual path of a generated file.
The full physical path to a generated file.
A containing the virtual path for filePath.
filePath is null.
Gets the physical path to the generated file for a virtual path.
The virtual path of the file to retrieve.
A <xref href="System.String"></xref> that contains the physical path to the generated file.
virtualPath is null.
Returns an array of the assemblies defined in the Bin directory and the `<assembly>` section of the Web configuration file.
The configuration name and path.
A <xref href="System.String"></xref> array containing paths to code bases in the Bin directory and the `<assembly>` section of the Web configuration file.
virtualPath is null.
Returns the virtual paths to the App_Code directory and its subdirectories in an ASP.NET application.
A <xref href="System.String"></xref> array containing all the virtual paths to code directories in an application.
Gives the application domain an infinite lifetime by preventing a lease from being created.
This method overrides the <xref:System.MarshalByRefObject.InitializeLifetimeService%2A> method in its base class.
It always returns `null` and thereby prevents a lease from being created that would limit the application domain's lifetime.
Always `null`.
Indicates whether an assembly is a code assembly.
The name of the assembly to be identified as a code assembly.
`true` if the assemblyName parameter matches one of the generated code assemblies; otherwise, `false`.
assemblyName is null.
Gets a value that indicates whether an application domain for compiling ASP.NET Web applications has been created.
`true` if the application domain for compiling ASP.NET Web applications has been created; otherwise, `false`.
Precompiles an ASP.NET application.
ASP.NET supports three forms of precompilation.
One form allows for the in-place precompilation of an ASP.NET application.
In this form, the site is deployed to production and then precompiled, which eliminates the need to dynamically compile the site when it is first visited by a user.
The first user of the site will not experience the delay normally encountered on a site that is dynamically compiled.
The two other forms of precompilation are used for deployment.
In either form, a layout of the site is generated that can be deployed to a production computer.
One of these forms includes the markup pages so some amount of updating can be performed on the compiled site.
The other form does not contain the markup pages and therefore cannot be updated without recompiling the original site.
No source code is deployed to the target environment in either of these forms of precompilation.
The application to precompile is defined through the <xref:System.Web.Compilation.ClientBuildManager> constructor.

The <xref:System.Web.Compilation.ClientBuildManagerParameter> object of the <xref:System.Web.Compilation.ClientBuildManager.%23ctor%2A> constructor defines which of the three forms of precompilation to perform.
A developer can precompile a Web site with the `aspnet_compiler` command-line tool or by calling the <xref:System.Web.Compilation.ClientBuildManager.PrecompileApplication%2A> method.
Precompiles an ASP.NET application and provides a callback method to receive status information about the build.
ASP.NET supports three forms of precompilation.
One form allows for the in-place precompilation of an ASP.NET application.
In this form, the site is deployed to production and then precompiled, which eliminates the need to dynamically compile the site when it is first visited by a user.
The first user of the site will not experience the delay normally encountered on a site that is dynamically compiled.
The `callback` parameter contains the method to call when reporting the result of compilation.
The two other forms of precompilation are used for deployment.
In either form, a layout of the site is generated that can be deployed to a production computer.
One of these forms includes the markup pages so some amount of updating can be performed on the compiled site.
The other form does not contain the markup pages and therefore cannot be updated without recompiling the original site.
No source code is deployed to the target environment in either of these forms of precompilation.
The application to precompile is defined through the <xref:System.Web.Compilation.ClientBuildManager> constructor.

The <xref:System.Web.Compilation.ClientBuildManagerParameter> object of the <xref:System.Web.Compilation.ClientBuildManager.%23ctor%2A> constructor defines which of the three forms of precompilation to perform.
A developer can precompile a Web site with the `aspnet_compiler` command-line tool or by calling the <xref:System.Web.Compilation.ClientBuildManager.PrecompileApplication%2A> method.
A <xref href="System.Web.Compilation.ClientBuildManagerCallback"></xref> containing the method to call when reporting the result of compilation.
Precompiles an ASP.NET application, provides a callback method to receive status information about the build, and indicates whether to create a clean build.
ASP.NET supports three forms of precompilation.
One form allows for the in-place precompilation of an ASP.NET application.
In this form, the site is deployed to production and then precompiled, which eliminates the need to dynamically compile the site when it is first visited by a user.
The first user of the site will not experience the delay normally encountered on a site that is dynamically compiled.
The `callback` parameter contains the method to call when reporting the result of compilation.
The two other forms of precompilation are used for deployment.
In either form, a layout of the site is generated that can be deployed to a production computer.
One of these forms includes the markup pages so some amount of updating can be performed on the compiled site.
The other form does not contain the markup pages and therefore cannot be updated without recompiling the original site.
No source code is deployed to the target environment in either of these forms of precompilation.
The application to precompile is defined through the <xref:System.Web.Compilation.ClientBuildManager> constructor.

The <xref:System.Web.Compilation.ClientBuildManagerParameter> object of the <xref:System.Web.Compilation.ClientBuildManager.%23ctor%2A> constructor defines which of the three forms of precompilation to perform.
A developer can precompile a Web site with the `aspnet_compiler` command-line tool or by calling the <xref:System.Web.Compilation.ClientBuildManager.PrecompileApplication%2A> method.
A <xref href="System.Web.Compilation.ClientBuildManagerCallback"></xref> containing the method to call when reporting the result of compilation.
`true` to perform a clean build, which will first delete all object and intermediate files; `false` to rebuild only those files that have changed.
Set to true if there is a chance that a dependency might not be picked up by the build environment.
Unloads the application domain for compiling ASP.NET Web applications.
`true` if the application domain is unloaded; otherwise, `false`.
Terminates the current ASP.NET application.
